text: If the XY problem means asking question Y while actually needing info about X, then the PQ problem is the complementary situation when someone answers question Q even though P was asked, because the responder only knows something about Q.

elements.text: If the XY problem means asking question Y while actually needing info about X, then the PQ problem is the complementary situation when someone answers question Q even though P was asked, because the responder only knows something about Q.

text: This hit me deep. I suffer from the PQ problem regularly :stuck_out_tongue:

text: Thats why I hang out here, people have really good answers for things

text: My PQ answer to any question of the type “how can I make my Python/Numpy code faster” is “rewrite it in Julia!”

elements.text: My PQ answer to any question of the type “how can I make my Python/Numpy code faster” is “rewrite it in Julia!”

text: I used to do that but then people go "I use Numba" or "Cython"

text: But Numba is only allows a subset of Python/Numpy, at least, from what I’ve heard.

text: Cython seems more interesting to me, as a means of better interoperating with Julia :slightly_smiling_face:

text: I never used Numba, but I have used Cython. Cython at least 2yrs ago or so, was a bad experience. It broke tons of dependencies and required you to use a NumPy from like 10 yrs prior

text: I’d been thinking it might be useful for 1) eeking out some more performance from old Python code that people don’t feel like rewriting in Julia (or don’t have time to) and 2) making it easier for those libraries to be *called* directly by Julia.

elements.text: I’d been thinking it might be useful for 1) eeking out some more performance from old Python code that people don’t feel like rewriting in Julia (or don’t have time to) and 2) making it easier for those libraries to be

text: I'm a little torn, if you look at some of the libraries in python, they really should just be used in python. I mean if it's a single function call or whatever, why not, but people write python packages to be more of an environment. Wereas a Julia package, it's more common for people to just drop a type, or a couple functions. So some of these packages either need complete ports (+ maintenance) or, they are probably are best left in separate toolchains.

elements.text: I'm a little torn, if you look at some of the libraries in python, they really should just be used in python. I mean if it's a single function call or whatever, why not, but people write python packages to be more of an environment. Wereas a Julia package, it's more common for people to just drop a type, or a couple functions. So some of these packages either need complete ports (+ maintenance) or, they are probably are best left in separate toolchains.
